repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Fixes #5393

> Note: documentation needs to be updated too

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -9079,7 +9079,7 @@ class ParallelStatNode(StatNode, ParallelNode):
                                 construct (replaced by its compile time value)
     """
 
-    child_attrs = ['body', 'num_threads']
+    child_attrs = ['body', 'num_threads', 'if_']

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    if_ = None
```

I think I prefer `if_` anyway
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -9090,6 +9090,7 @@ class ParallelStatNode(StatNode, ParallelNode):
 
     num_threads = None
     chunksize = None
+    _if = None

@@ -9090,6 +9090,7 @@ class ParallelStatNode(StatNode, ParallelNode):
 
     num_threads = None
     chunksize = None
+    _if = None

comment_data.body:
This seems a useless comment. Why add an additional comment line to code that does exactly what the comment says in just two clear lines?
```suggestion
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -9793,9 +9805,17 @@ def generate_execution_code(self, code):
         self.declare_closure_privates(code)
         self.setup_parallel_control_flow_block(code)
 
+        if self.if_ is not None:
+            self.if_.generate_evaluation_code(code)
+
         code.putln("#ifdef _OPENMP")
         code.put("#pragma omp parallel ")
 
+        # Add if statement, if present

comment_data.body:
It's bad enough to make users write option names with underscores at end (or start), but we shouldn't do this internally, and there is no reason to use the same name for both the user visible option and the internal representation. We can name the internal variables/attributes `threading_condition`, for example. Trailing underscores disrupt the reading and make readers think, entirely unnecessarily.

We can also name the user option `only_if`. `parallel(only_if=condition)` reads even a bit better to me than a blank `if`, I think, let alone a distracting `if_`. `use_threads_if=condition` seems even more descriptive and does not even need a reference to the OMP spec.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -9079,7 +9079,7 @@ class ParallelStatNode(StatNode, ParallelNode):
                                 construct (replaced by its compile time value)
     """
 
-    child_attrs = ['body', 'num_threads']
+    child_attrs = ['body', 'num_threads', 'if_']

comment_data.body:
The spacing looks wrong here.
```suggestion
            code.put("if(%s) " % self.if_.result())
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -9793,9 +9805,17 @@ def generate_execution_code(self, code):
         self.declare_closure_privates(code)
         self.setup_parallel_control_flow_block(code)
 
+        if self.if_ is not None:
+            self.if_.generate_evaluation_code(code)
+
         code.putln("#ifdef _OPENMP")
         code.put("#pragma omp parallel ")
 
+        # Add if statement, if present
+        if self.if_ is not None:
+            code.put(" if(%s)" % self.if_.result())

comment_data.body:
This seems a useless (and misleading) comment. There is only one such statement, and it is _obviously_ added to the code here.
```suggestion
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -10099,6 +10122,11 @@ def generate_loop(self, code, fmt_dict):
             reduction_codepoint = self.parent.privatization_insertion_point
         else:
             code.put("#pragma omp parallel")
+
+            # Add if-statements to code

comment_data.body: As I have mentioned, `if_` is not final version. I wanted to have something just to finish implementation. I am open to any suggestion. I like `use_threads_if` more, so I will use it instead of `if_`. If there will be consensus on other name I am fine to change it again.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -9079,7 +9079,7 @@ class ParallelStatNode(StatNode, ParallelNode):
                                 construct (replaced by its compile time value)
     """
 
-    child_attrs = ['body', 'num_threads']
+    child_attrs = ['body', 'num_threads', 'if_']

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
                error(self.pos, "'use_threads_if' must de declared in the parent parallel section")
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -9170,6 +9175,12 @@ def analyse_expressions(self, env):
         if self.num_threads:
             self.num_threads = self.num_threads.analyse_expressions(env)
 
+        if self.use_threads_if:
+            if self.is_parallel:
+                self.use_threads_if = self.use_threads_if.analyse_expressions(env)
+            else:
+                error(self.pos, "if_ must de declared in the parent parallel section")

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
            # Try to find known keyword arguments.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -9132,9 +9133,10 @@ def analyse_declarations(self, env):
         self.body.analyse_declarations(env)
 
         self.num_threads = None
+        self.use_threads_if = None
 
         if self.kwargs:
-            # Try to find num_threads and chunksize keyword arguments
+            # Try to find num_threads, if_ and chunksize keyword arguments

@@ -9773,15 +9784,23 @@ def redef_builtin_expect_apple_gcc_bug(self, code):
         if not self.parent:
             code.redef_builtin_expect(self.redef_condition)
 
+    def _parameters_nogil_check(self, env, names, nodes):
+        for name, node in zip(names, nodes):
+            if node is not None and node.type.is_pyobject:
+                error(node.pos, "%s may not be a Python object "
+                                "as we don't have the GIL" % name)
+
+
 
 class ParallelWithBlockNode(ParallelStatNode):
     """
     This node represents a 'with cython.parallel.parallel():' block
     """
 
-    valid_keyword_arguments = ['num_threads']
+    valid_keyword_arguments = ['num_threads', 'use_threads_if']
 
     num_threads = None
+    if_ = None

@@ -9822,11 +9849,22 @@ def generate_execution_code(self, code):
         return_ = code.label_used(code.return_label)
 
         self.restore_labels(code)
+
+        # ------ cleanup ------
         self.end_parallel_control_flow_block(code, break_=break_,
                                              continue_=continue_,
                                              return_=return_)
+
+        if self.use_threads_if is not None:
+            self.use_threads_if.generate_disposal_code(code)
+            self.use_threads_if.free_temps(code)
+
         self.release_closure_privates(code)
 
+    def nogil_check(self, env):
+        names = 'use_threads_if',

@@ -10035,6 +10070,9 @@ def generate_execution_code(self, code):
 
             fmt_dict[name] = result
 
+        if self.use_threads_if is not None:
+            x = self.use_threads_if.generate_evaluation_code(code)

comment_data.body: This looks like a case that we should support. Not necessarily right now from the start, but it seems unexpected that the Python condition is not being evaluated as part of the `prange()` function call but only after releasing the GIL (which is simply triggered by another argument to the same function call). The order in which we release the GIL and evaluate the condition should be up to us and not get in the way of the users.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -149,6 +149,26 @@ with nogil, cython.parallel.parallel():
     with cython.parallel.parallel():
         pass
 
+cdef bint gil_function():
+    return True
+
+for i in prange(10, nogil=True, use_threads_if=gil_function()):
+    pass
+
+with nogil, parallel.parallel(use_threads_if=gil_function()):
+    pass
+
+def bar():
+
+    python_var = object()
+
+    cdef int i
+
+    for i in prange(10, nogil=True, use_threads_if=python_var):
+        pass

comment_data.body:
> This looks like a case that we should support. 

I agree. I did it in this way because this is the way how `prange()` works currently and it is simple to implement this way.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -149,6 +149,26 @@ with nogil, cython.parallel.parallel():
     with cython.parallel.parallel():
         pass
 
+cdef bint gil_function():
+    return True
+
+for i in prange(10, nogil=True, use_threads_if=gil_function()):
+    pass
+
+with nogil, parallel.parallel(use_threads_if=gil_function()):
+    pass
+
+def bar():
+
+    python_var = object()
+
+    cdef int i
+
+    for i in prange(10, nogil=True, use_threads_if=python_var):
+        pass

comment_data.body:
Doesn't have to be the Python value `True`.
```suggestion
        is evaluated as true. Otherwise the code is run sequentially. Running
```

@@ -52,6 +52,12 @@ It currently supports OpenMP, but later on more backends might be supported.
         This function can only be used with the GIL released.
         If ``nogil`` is true, the loop will be wrapped in a nogil section.
 
+    :param use_threads_if: The loop is run in multiple threads only if ``CONDITION``
+        is evaluated as ``True``. Otherwise the code is run sequentially. Running

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
        threads is greater than the benefit of running the loop in parallel
        (e.g. for small data sets).
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -52,6 +52,12 @@ It currently supports OpenMP, but later on more backends might be supported.
         This function can only be used with the GIL released.
         If ``nogil`` is true, the loop will be wrapped in a nogil section.
 
+    :param use_threads_if: The loop is run in multiple threads only if ``CONDITION``
+        is evaluated as ``True``. Otherwise the code is run sequentially. Running
+        the loop sequentially can be handy in the cases when the cost of spawning
+        threads is greater than the benefirt of running the loop in parallel
+        (e.g. for small data set).

         .. literalinclude:: ../../examples/userguide/parallelism/memoryview_sum.pyx

title: Add `if` parameter to `parallel()` and `prange()`
